name: Buddhist Mythology
description: One of the central virtues in Buddhism, the wish for all beings to be free from suffering. Combined with wisdom, compassion is the foundation of the bodhisattva path and is personified by Avalokiteshvara.

philosophicalMeaning.universalLove: Karuna as universal compassion without partiality parallels the philosophical concept of agape - love that extends to all regardless of merit
philosophicalMeaning.wisdomAndLove: The pairing of karuna (compassion) with prajna (wisdom) mirrors the Christian integration of love and truth, mercy and justice
philosophicalMeaning.responsiveness: Compassion as active response to suffering reflects the theological understanding of divine providence and care for creatures
philosophicalMeaning.transformativeVirtue: Compassion transforms both giver and receiver, echoing the Christian understanding of charity as the form of all virtues

theologicalSignificance.divineAttribute: Buddhist compassion points toward the theological truth that God is love (1 John 4:8) and desires mercy over sacrifice (Hosea 6:6)
theologicalSignificance.christlikeLove: The aspiration to relieve all suffering resonates with Christ's compassion for the crowds 'harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd' (Matthew 9:36)
theologicalSignificance.salvificMotivation: As karuna motivates the bodhisattva path, so divine love motivates the Incarnation: 'God so loved the world' (John 3:16)
theologicalSignificance.covenantFaithfulness: The steadfast, unconditional nature of karuna echoes the Hebrew concept of hesed - God's covenant love and mercy

practicalApplications: Buddhist compassion practices offer contemplative methods that can deepen Christian understanding of neighbor-love and the corporal works of mercy
definition: Karuna - the Buddhist virtue of wishing all beings freedom from suffering, paired with wisdom (prajna) as the fundamental basis for enlightenment and ethical conduct.
examples: Compassionate witnessing of suffering without turning away
Extending loving-kindness equally to enemies and loved ones
Working to relieve hunger, disease, and ignorance

christian.agapeLove: Karuna parallels agape - the unconditional, self-giving love central to Christian ethics (1 Corinthians 13)
christian.divineMercy: The Buddhist emphasis on compassion reflects the theological truth of God's mercy (rachamim) shown throughout salvation history
christian.beatitudes: Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy (Matthew 5:7) - compassion as both gift and calling
christian.parable: The Good Samaritan (Luke 10:25-37) embodies the active, boundary-crossing compassion karuna aspires to
christian.corporialWorks: Buddhist compassion practices align with the corporal works of mercy: feeding the hungry, clothing the naked, visiting the sick

comparativeNotes.naturalTheology: The universal recognition of compassion as a supreme virtue demonstrates moral truths accessible through natural reason (Romans 2:14-15), pointing to the God who 'is kind to the ungrateful and the evil' (Luke 6:35)

patristicCommentary.johnChrysostom: Chrysostom's extensive homilies on almsgiving and compassion for the poor resonate with Buddhist emphasis on active compassion toward all beings
patristicCommentary.augustine: Augustine's teaching that love (caritas) orders all other virtues parallels the Buddhist understanding of compassion as foundational
patristicCommentary.gregoryOfNyssa: Gregory's concept of epektasis - endless growth in divine love - echoes the boundless expansion of compassion in Mahayana practice
patristicCommentary.thomasAquinas: Aquinas's teaching that mercy is God's supreme attribute in relation to creatures (Summa Theologiae I.21.3) resonates with karuna as supreme Buddhist virtue

biblicalParallels: 1 John 4:7-12 - God is love; whoever abides in love abides in God
Matthew 9:36 - Christ's compassion for the crowds, harassed and helpless
Luke 6:36 - Be merciful, as your Father is merciful
Colossians 3:12 - Put on compassion, kindness, humility, meekness, patience
Micah 6:8 - What does the Lord require? To do justice, love mercy, walk humbly
Matthew 25:31-46 - The Last Judgment based on compassionate action toward 'the least of these'
typologicalReading: Buddhist karuna represents humanity's natural aspiration toward the infinite compassion fully revealed in Christ, who 'had compassion on them' (Matthew 14:14) and whose heart was 'moved with pity' for human suffering - the fulfillment of what all compassion anticipates
